sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The maxnat function is used to determine the largest natural number that can be used in a program.
sections.mdown_content: The **maxnat** function is used to determine the largest natural number that can be used in a program.

sections.title: Example
code: put "The largest natural number that can be used is ", maxnat
sections.raw_content: This program outputs the maximum natural number.
sections.mdown_content: This program outputs the maximum natural number.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content:
In current implementations, natural numbers are stored in 4 bytes, i.e., 32 bits. This determines the maximum natural number, which is 2**32 - 2, equaling 4294967294.

In four bytes it is possible to represent one more value, namely, 2**32 - 1 = 4294967295. This extra value is used in Turing to represent the uninitialized natural number. Although it can be computed, any attempt to assign it to a nat variable is detected as an overflow. You can use this extra value by using the nat4 type instead of nat, but this type has no initialization checking.
sections.mdown_content:
In current  implementations, natural numbers are stored in 4 bytes, i.e., 32 bits. This determines the maximum natural number, which is 2**32 - 2, equaling 4294967294.
In four bytes it is possible to represent one more value, namely, 2**32 - 1 = 4294967295. This extra value is used in Turing to represent the uninitialized natural number. Although it can be computed, any attempt to assign it to a **nat** variable is detected as an overflow. You can use this extra value by using the **nat4** type instead of **nat**, but this type has no initialization checking.

sections.title: See also
sections.raw_content:
maxint and minnat.

See also predefined unit Limits.
